citeinfo.title: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2016_IN.SHP: Locations of Operation for Active Industrial Minerals Producers in 2016 in Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, Point Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: This shapefile was derived from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet named "MINDIR2016.xls" that was obtained from a publication of the Indiana Geological Survey about industrial minerals producers in Indiana as of 2016.

descript.abstract: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2016_IN.SHP is a point shapefile that shows the locations of operation for industrial minerals producers that were active in 2016 in Indiana. These operations extract and (or) produce the following commodities: cement, clay and shale, crushed stone, dimension limestone, dimension sandstone, gypsum, lime, peat, slag, and sand and gravel. The data set contains location, contact information, geologic information, and other relevant information for all industrial minerals operations known to be active in Indiana on 20160415.
descript.purpose: INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2016_IN.SHP was created to provide information about active industrial minerals producers in 2016 in Indiana, that suitable for use in a GIS.

idinfo.native: ESRI ArcGIS 10.3 shapefile format, approximately 1.71 Mb

attracc.attraccr: The data contained in this shapefile was extracted from a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet named "MINDIR2016.xls" produced by the Indiana Geological Survey in 2016. The data from the spreadsheet is assumed to be complete and accurate.

dataqual.complete: This shapefile represents more than 90 percent of industrial mineral operations that were active in Indiana in 2016. Some operations may have been omitted that were not subject to federal or state regulation because of their relatively small size and (or) because of their lack of adverse effects on the environment. The primary source of information for the data set was the U.S. Department of Labor, Mine Safety and Health Administration. Other sources included the Indiana Mineral Aggregates Association membership directory, telephone listings, aggregate source lists compiled by the Indiana Department of Transportation, company websites, neighboring businesses, the Indiana Secretary of State’s website, conversations with geologists, and information from the Executive Director of the Indiana Mineral Aggregates Association.

horizpa.horizpar: Location data were verified by past geologist visits to the industrial minerals operations, checked against U.S. Geological Survey 7.5-minute topographic maps, and checked against satellite images. Locations of 4 of the new operations were verified from information provided by the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration because they were so new that they were not yet displaying on online maps.

vertacc.vertaccr: The vertical positional accuracy was not a factor in the digital production of these data.

citeinfo.title: MinDIR2016.XLS: Directory of Industrial Mineral Producers in Indiana (Microsoft Excel Spreadsheet)

srcinfo.srccontr: Locations of operation for producers of industrial minerals in Indiana, 2016. Data include types of materials produced and information such as mine name, address, contact information, etc.

procstep.procdesc: During the summer of 2001, staff of the Mineral Resources Section of the Indiana Geological Survey conducted field work to collect mine location data using a Trimble GeoExplorer III GPS unit. These data were downloaded to Trimble Pathfinder Office for processing and exported as an ESRI ArcView shapefile. The theme attribute table was converted to a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet named "ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS." Company and commodity data from the 2001 Directory of Industrial Mineral Producers in Indiana were directly entered into that spreadsheet.
procstep.srcused: Active industrial minerals operation in study area.XLS

procstep.procdesc:
The Microsoft Excel spreadsheet ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS was saved as a dBase III file named "ACTIVEMINES2001.DBF." The file ACTIVEMINES2001.DBF was added to an ESRI ArcView project as a table. The "Add Event Theme" and "Convert to Shapefile" functions were used to import the table into an ArcView View and to convert the table to a shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN.
The shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN was then edited in ESRI ArcView. Of the 363 records in ACTIVEMINES2001.XLS there were 320 records that had complete locational information in the form of UTMx and UTMy coordinates. Records without such locational information were deleted from the shapefile. Of the 320 records with complete locational information, there were 314 records that had complete information regarding the name of the mine, pit, quarry, plant, and (or) company. Points lacking such information were deleted from the shapefile.
Additional editing of the shapefile INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN was then conducted. The following fields were added: Commodity1, Commodity2, and Commodity3. Using the "Calculator" function, values in the field named "Commodity1" were set equal to values in the field named "Type." Records having no locational information but that had company information were used to fill in the fields Commodity2 and Commodity3. Finally, the following fields were then removed from the shapefile: Type, Quadrangle, Qtr, Sec, T, R, County_nam, Longitude, Latitude, and Number.

The Microsoft Excel spreadsheet "IMDIR10.XLS" was saved as a comma-delimited text file named "IMDIR10.TXT." IMDIR10.TXT was then added to an Esri ArcMap document, and the "Display XY Data" function was used to display the data using the UTM Zone 16, NAD 1983 latitude and longitude values contained in the original database. The layer named "LANDSURVEY_STATE_BOUNDARY_IN.SHP" was also loaded into ArcMap to ensure that all points generated from the X-Y coordinates were located within the geographic region of Indiana. The "Data > Export Data" function was then used to produce an Esri point shapefile named "INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2001_IN.SHP" to conform to the file-naming conventions of the IGS. Finally, the following fields were then removed from the attribute table of the shapefile: "Record_ID," "Quadrangle," "Sec_Twp," "County," and "Map_ID_Num."

The Microsoft Excel spreadsheet "MINDIR2016.XLS" was saved as a comma-delimited text file named "MINDIR2016.TXT." IMDIR10.TXT was then added to an Esri ArcMap document, and the "Display XY Data" function was used to display the data using the UTM Zone 16, NAD 1983 latitude and longitude values contained in the original database. The layer named "LANDSURVEY_STATE_BOUNDARY_IN.SHP" was also loaded into ArcMap to ensure that all points generated from the X-Y coordinates were located within the geographic region of Indiana. The "Data > Export Data" function was then used to produce an Esri point shapefile named "INDUSTRIAL_MINDERALS_ACTIVE_2016_IN.SHP" to conform to the file-naming conventions of the IGS. Finally, the following fields were then removed from the attribute table of the shapefile: "Record_ID," "Quadrangle," "Sec_Twp," "County," and "Map_ID_Num."

This metadata was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit) and MP (Metadata Parser) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected, except that no values were assigned to "Abscissa_Resolution" and "Ordinate_Resolution."

attr.attrdef: Unique identification number for the mine/plant (assigned by the IGS)
Name of the county in Indiana in which the mine/plant is located
Mineral commodity produced at the mine/plant

edom.edomvd: Sand and gravel (for construction) is produced

attr.attrdef: Name of the company that owns the mine/plant
Information if the company is known to be a division or subsidiary of another company
Mailing address for the regional corporate office of the company
City, State, and Zip Code for the regional corporate office
Telephone number(s) for the regional corporate office
Fax telephone number for the regional corporate office
The website URL for the company, if available
Electronic mail (E-mail) address for the company
Name by which the mine/plant is known

Mailing address for the mine/plant, if one exists. In some cases, the mine address listed is a mine location, but not a mailing address. In those cases, a zip code is not included in the following field and a three-letter state abbreviation (Ind.) is used in that field instead of the two-letter state abbreviation that is used with zip codes (IN) and “(no mail receptacle)” is added. The mailing address listed under regional corporate address should be used for those companies. Addresses are not repeated in this field for small companies whose addresses have been listed in the regional corporate office fields.
City, state, and zip code for the mine/plant. In some cases this is not a part of a mailing address, but an indication of where the mine/plant is located, as explained under the previous attribute.

Telephone number used at the mine or plant. If this field is blank, there is no telephone at the mine or plant or the number is the same as that listed under the regional corporate telephone field. Information in most cases is not duplicated under different fields.

Fax number used at the mine/plant. If this field is blank, the fax number is unknown, there is no fax machine at the mine/plant, or the number is the same as that listed under the regional corporate fax field. Information in most cases is not duplicated under different fields.
Electronic mail (E-mail) address for the mine/plant
General locality of the mine/plant, in most cases stated as distance and direction from landmarks such as cities, towns, road junctions, etc.
U.S. Geological Survey 7.5-minute quadrangle in which mine or plant is located
Abbreviation for section, township, and range (Congressional land survey location) of mine or plant
Description of products produced by the mine/plant
Stratigraphic units produced at the mine/plant, and thicknesses, where known
General comments regarding the mine/plant

A unique source number assigned by the Indiana Department of Transportation (INDOT) for a particular producer of road construction materials. Some numbers within this range are not currently being used by an active producer. Not all producers have INDOT source numbers (values of zero). A producer with an INDOT source number is not a certified aggregate producer unless it also has a "Certified Aggregate Producers Program" (CAPP) number.

Certified Aggregate Producers Program number (Indiana Department of Transportation). Indicates that an aggregate producer has completed requirements of the Certified Aggregate Producer Program and has received certification to provide materials for Indiana Department of Transportation projects. The number is a unique number assigned by INDOT for a particular producer. All numbers are preceded by the letter Q. The first two numbers indicate the year that the operation received certification. A missing number within the range indicates either that the number has been assigned to a producer that has not yet completed all requirements of the CAPP program, or that a certified producer is not currently producing. Not all producers have CAPP numbers.

Unique identifying number assigned to producers by the U.S. Department of Labor, Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA). The number “12” at the start of every number means that the producer is located in the state of Indiana. Not all producers have MSHA-identifying numbers.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Labor, Mine Safety and Health Administration

attr.attrdef: X (or Easting) coordinate (UTM Zone 16 NAD83, units are in meters) of the mine/plant, for mapping purposes
Y (or Northing) coordinate (UTM Zone 16 NAD83, units are in meters) of the mine/plant, for mapping purposes
Date that the data was entered or checked in the IGS database

distinfo.distliab:
CREDIT
It is requested that the Indiana Geological Survey be cited in any products generated from this data. The following source citation should be included: [INDUSTRIAL_MINERALS_ACTIVE_2016_IN.SHP: Locations of Operation for Active Industrial Minerals Producers in 2016 in Indiana (Indiana Geological Survey, Point Shapefile), compiled by Kathryn R. Shaffer, 20160506].
WARRANTY
Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey warrants that the media on which this product is stored will be free from defect in materials and workmanship for ninety (90) days from the date of acquisition. If such a defect is found, return the media to Publication Sales, Indiana Geological Survey, 611 North Walnut Grove, Bloomington, Indiana 47405 2208, and it will be replaced free of charge.
LIMITATION OF WARRANTIES AND LIABILITY
Except for the expressed warranty above, the product is provided "AS IS", without any other warranties or conditions, expressed or implied, including, but not limited to, warranties for product quality, or suitability to a particular purpose or use. The risk or liability resulting from the use of this product is assumed by the user. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey shares no liability with product users indirect, incidental, special, or consequential damages whatsoever, including, but not limited to, loss of revenue or profit, lost or damaged data or other commercial or economic loss. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey is not responsible for claims by a third party. The maximum aggregate liability to the original purchaser shall not exceed the amount paid by you for the product.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It should not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
